question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix}.$  Compute
\[\mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb.\]
inference:
Let $S = \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb$.
We have $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix}$. Note that
\[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 15(15)+25(-9) & 15(25)+25(-15) \\ -9(15)+(-15)(-9) & -9(25)+(-15)(-15) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]
Thus, $\mathbf{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$, and so on.
Thus, for $n \ge 2$, $\mathbf{A}^n = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$.
Then
\begin{align*} S &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty (n+1) \mathbf{A}^n \\ &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb \\ &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} + 2 \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 50 \\ -18 & -30 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 31 & 50 \\ -18 & -29 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}
Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 31 & 50 \\ -18 & -29 \end{pmatrix}}$
ground_truth:
Note that
\[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{0}.\]Therefore, $\mathbf{A}^n = \mathbf{0}$ for all $n \ge 2,$ which means
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} + 2 \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 31 & 50 \\ -18 & -29 \end{pmatrix}}.
\end{align*}

question:

We have $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix}$. Note that
\[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 15(15)+25(-9) & 15(25)+25(-15) \\ -9(15)+(-15)(-9) & -9(25)+(-15)(-15) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]
Thus, $\mathbf{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$, and so on.
Thus, for $n \ge 2$, $\mathbf{A}^n = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$.
Then
\begin{align*} S &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty (n+1) \mathbf{A}^n \\ &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb \\ &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} + 2 \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 50 \\ -18 & -30 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 31 & 50 \\ -18 & -29 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}

inference:
Let $S = \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb = \sum_{n=0}^\infty (n+1) \mathbf{A}^n$.
The given matrix is $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix}$.  We have $\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$.
Then $\mathbf{A}^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$, and in general $\mathbf{A}^n = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$ for all $n \ge 2$.
The series is
\begin{align*} S &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty (n+1) \mathbf{A}^n \\ &= \mathbf{A}^0 + 2 \mathbf{A}^1 + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb \\ &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb \end{align*}
Since $\mathbf{A}^n = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$ for all $n \ge 2$,
\begin{align*} S &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + \sum_{n=2}^\infty (n+1) \mathbf{A}^n \\ &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + \sum_{n=2}^\infty (n+1) \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} + 2 \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 50 \\ -18 & -30 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 31 & 50 \\ -18 & -29 \end{pmatrix} \end{align*}

Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 31 & 50 \\ -18 & -29 \end{pmatrix}}$
ground_truth:
Note that
\[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{0}.\]Therefore, $\mathbf{A}^n = \mathbf{0}$ for all $n \ge 2,$ which means
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} + 3 \mathbf{A}^2 + 4 \mathbf{A}^3 + \dotsb &= \mathbf{I} + 2 \mathbf{A} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} + 2 \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 25 \\ -9 & -15 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 31 & 50 \\ -18 & -29 \end{pmatrix}}.
\end{align*}
